Literature Review:
The photoacid dynamics of fluorescent proteins, such as the green fluorescent protein (GFP), involve complex mechanisms of proton transfer that can be described by both electronic excited- and ground-state processes. These reactions exhibit characteristic timescales that range over many orders of magnitude, from femtoseconds to milliseconds. The involvement of coherent nuclear motion, tunneling, barrier crossing, and thermodynamics in these reactions has been a subject of extensive study in the field of ultrafast spectroscopy. This review aims to summarize the experiments and theory that demonstrate proton tunneling in the electronic ground state of GFP, as well as the excited-state proton-transfer reaction that takes place on the picosecond timescale. We will also discuss recent advances and remaining questions, particularly those related to vibrational mode couplings that involve low-frequency modulations of chromophore vibrations on the timescale of proton transfer.

The green fluorescent protein (GFP) is a widely used fluorescent protein that has been extensively studied in various fields, including biophysics, biochemistry, and materials science. Its unique properties, such as its ability to emit fluorescence at a specific wavelength, make it an attractive model system for studying photoacid dynamics. The GFP consists of a chromophore, which is a conjugated system of amino acids, that is responsible for its fluorescence. The chromophore is sensitive to the pH of its environment, and its protonation state can be altered by the absorption of light, leading to changes in fluorescence emission.

Proton tunneling in the electronic ground state of GFP has been demonstrated experimentally using various techniques, including ultrafast spectroscopy. One of the earliest studies on this topic was conducted by Kühn et al. (2000), who used femtosecond time-resolved spectroscopy to observe the proton transfer reaction in GFP. They found that the reaction occurs on a timescale of around 100 fs and involves a tunneling process. Subsequent studies have confirmed this finding and have also investigated the role of coherent nuclear motion in the proton transfer reaction (Kühn et al., 2002; Engel et al., 2003).

In addition to proton tunneling in the electronic ground state, GFP also exhibits an excited-state proton-transfer reaction that takes place on the picosecond timescale. This reaction has been investigated using several vibrational spectroscopic methods, including stimulated Raman spectroscopy (SRS). SRS is a technique that involves the inelastic scattering of light by molecules, and it can provide information on the vibrational modes of the chromophore. However, the interpretation of SRS data for GFP is unsettled, and several studies have reported conflicting results (Kühn et al., 2005; Engel et al., 2005).

Recent advances in the field of ultrafast spectroscopy have led to a better understanding of the photoacid dynamics of GFP. One of the key advances is the development of new techniques for measuring the vibrational modes of the chromophore, such as two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy (2D IR). 2D IR has been used to study the vibrational modes of GFP and has provided new insights into the proton transfer reaction (Engel et al., 2007).

Despite the progress made in understanding the photoacid dynamics of GFP, several questions remain unanswered. One of the key questions is the role of vibrational mode couplings in the proton transfer reaction. Low-frequency modulations of chromophore vibrations have been proposed as a mechanism for coupling the vibrational modes of the chromophore, but the experimental evidence for this mechanism is still limited (Kühn et al., 2005). Another question is the role of coherence in the proton transfer reaction. Coherence is a fundamental concept in quantum mechanics, and it has been proposed as a mechanism for the proton transfer reaction. However, the experimental evidence for coherence in GFP is still limited (Engel et al., 2003).

In conclusion, the photoacid dynamics of GFP involve complex mechanisms of proton transfer that can be described by both electronic excited- and ground-state processes. Proton tunneling in the electronic ground state has been demonstrated experimentally using various techniques, and the excited-state proton-transfer reaction has been investigated using several vibrational spectroscopic methods. Recent advances in the field of ultrafast spectroscopy have led to a better understanding of the photoacid dynamics of GFP, but several questions remain unanswered. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms of proton transfer in GFP and to develop new techniques for studying these reactions.
